head.title: Cadbury Expected to Sell Beverage Unit, Including 7-Up

hedline.hl1: Cadbury Expected to Sell Beverage Unit, Including 7-Up
hedline.hl2: Cadbury Expected to Sell Beverage Unit, Including 7-Up

body.head.byline: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN and MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

block.p: Cadbury Schweppes is preparing to announce tomorrow that is will sell its American beverage business, which includes 7-Up, Dr Pepper and Snapple, according to people close to the company.
Cadbury said in March that it would split its confectionary and soft drink businesses, but had not determined whether it would sell the beverage business or spin it off.
Cadbury Schweppes is preparing to announce on Tuesday that it will sell its American beverage business, according to people close to the company.
Cadbury Schweppes is preparing to announce tomorrow that is will sell its American beverage business, which includes 7-Up, Dr Pepper and Snapple, according to people close to the company.
Cadbury said in March that it would split its confectionary and soft drink businesses, but had not determined whether it would sell the beverage business or spin it off.

On Friday, the deadline for suitors to make an offer, Cadbury received at least three bids for the beverage business, worth about £8 billion ($15.8 billion). One bidding group includes Bain Capital Partners, Thomas H. Lee Partners and the Texas Pacific Group; a second consortium includes the Blackstone Group, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Lion Capital. (Lion and Blackstone acquired Cadbury's European beverage unit last year.)

Another bid came from a group led by Cott, a Canadian company that makes private-label drinks for retailers like Wal-Mart Stores. Should that bid be accepted, it would combine the world's third- and fourth-largest drink makers into a company that would still lag far behind the industry leaders, Coca-Cola and PepsiCo.
While it was unclear yesterday which bidder was the front-runner, Cadbury has told investors that it will provide an update on the breakup process tomorrow.
Since its announcement, Cadbury's stock has risen 30 percent.
A report in The Sunday Times of London said the company was considering a plan to eliminate 5,000 jobs as part of a £300 million cost-cutting effort.

Analysts said a sale of Cadbury's beverages unit would make sense, as the company could use the proceeds to bulk up its candy business. Among its most likely targets is Hershey, which owns a 45 percent share of the American chocolate market. The two companies already share a link: Hershey controls distribution of Cadbury's brands in the United States.

But Hershey's largest shareholder, the Hershey Trust Company, has thwarted takeover bids in the past. Five years ago, as Hershey prepared to announce a $12.5 billion merger with the Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company, the trust demanded that the deal be called off amid a furor in the Pennsylvania town that bears the chocolate maker's name.
The Hershey Trust also rejected a joint offer by Cadbury and Nestlé worth about $10.5 billion. Wrigley may also be a takeover candidate, albeit a less likely one, analysts have said.

Conversely, Cadbury's confectionary business could become a buyout target, with analysts citing Kraft as a potential buyer. Cadbury's drinks division, which also includes the Motts, Clamato and Yoo-Hoo brands, is among the company's most profitable, bringing in about £2.6 billion in revenue, 35 percent of the company's total, last year. The division, based in Plano, Tex., has more than 18,000 employees. Its parent is based in London.

Although the company made its announcement only days after Nelson Peltz, the shareholder activist and former owner of Snapple, said he had acquired a 3 percent stake, Cadbury said it had planned the divestment for some time.
